sen.j: 住友家の始祖
sen.e: Earliest ancestor of Sumitomo Family
Earliest ancestor of the Sumitomo Family
Earliest ancestor of the Sumitomo Family

sen.j: 住友の姓は、戦国の末、もともと先祖に順美平内友定という人物がおり、桓武天皇の曾孫・高望王の二十二代目にその子・小太郎（忠重）が父の姓と名をとって「住友」の姓を称して室町将軍に仕えて、備中守に任じられたのに始まる。
sen.e: The surname of Sumitomo originates from Kotaro (Tadashige), the 22nd generation descendant of Takamochi-oh who is a great grandson of Kanmu Emperor, who took the surname of "Sumitomo" after the surname and given name of his father, Masami Hirauchi Tomosada who lived in the end of Sengoku period, and Kotaro served Muromachi Shogun and was appointed to be Bichumori Guard.

The surname of Sumitomo originates from Kotaro (Tadashige), the twenty-second-generation descendant of Takamochi-oh, a great grandson of Emperor Kanmu, who took the surname "Sumitomo" after the surname and given name of his father, Masami Hirauchi Tomosada, who lived at the end of the Sengoku period; and Kotaro served Shogun Muromachi and was appointed as the Bichumori guard.
sen.cmt: This is generally a little hard to read but the main problem for the reader would be that the explanation of how the surname "Sumitomo" was created doesn't seem to make much sense. How do you get "Sumitomo" from "Masami" and "Tomosada"? It may be clear in Japanese, but an explanation that makes logical sense also needs to be provided in the English translation. 原文の「順美平内友定」という名前の姓と名をとるとなぜ「住友」になるのか、「順美」＝「住」と想像しウェブ等で調べましたが、確証がとれませんでした。
sen.e: The surname of Sumitomo originates from Kotaro (Tadashige), the twenty-second-generation descendant of Takamochi-oh, a great grandson of Emperor Kanmu, who took the surname "Sumitomo" after the surname and given name of his father, Masami Hirauchi Tomosada, who lived at the end of the Sengoku period; and Kotaro served Shogun Muromachi and was appointed as the Bichumori guard.

sen.j: 平家の末裔である戦国武士だった住友家の先祖は、国取り物語の戦国時代 (日本)を有為転変の歴史を生きる。
sen.e: The ancestors of Sumitomo Family, who were Sengoku Samurai and descendants of Heike, lived in a history of shifts and changes in the Sengoku Period (Japan) when warriors fighted against each other to expand their lands.

The ancestors of the Sumitomo Family, who were Sengoku samurai and descendants of Heike, lived during a history of shifts and changes in the Sengoku period of Japan, when warriors fought each other in order to expand their lands.

The ancestors of the Sumitomo Family, who were Sengoku samurai and descendants of Heike, lived during the tumultuous period of Japanese history known as the Sengoku period (Period of Warring States), when warriors fought each other in order to expand their lands.
sen.cmt: a history of shifts and changes in the Sengoku period→the tumultuous period of Japanese history known as Sengoku periodEven without looking at the Japanese, it seems safe to assume that "a history of shifts and changes in the Sengoku period" could probably be more naturally expressed as "the tumultuous period of Japanese history known as the Sengoku period (Period of Warring States)".

sen.j: 室町将軍に仕えた「始祖」・住友忠重の子・頼定は、足利義晴に仕え、頼定の子・定信は刑部承と称した。
sen.e: The "earliest ancestor" Tadashige SUMITOMO who served Muromachi Shogun had a son Yorisada who served Yoshiharu ASHIKAGA, and Yorisada's son Sadanobu called himself as Osakabe-sho.
The "earliest ancestor," Tadashige SUMITOMO, who served Shogun Muromachi, had a son called Yorisada who served Yoshiharu ASHIKAGA, and Yorisada's son Sadanobu called himself Osakabe-sho.
The "earliest ancestor," Tadashige SUMITOMO, who served Shogun Muromachi, had a son called Yorisada who served Yoshiharu ASHIKAGA, and Yorisada's son Sadanobu called himself Osakabe-sho.

sen.j: そして、定信の子・定重は、今川義忠（今川義元の祖父）に仕えるが、定重の子・信定の代になり、今川氏が滅んでしまったので、摂津の中川清秀に仕え、入江土佐守と称し、中川十六騎の一人として知られたが、尾崎の陣で戦死してしまう。
sen.e: And Sadanobu's son Sadashige served Yoshitada IMAGAWA (grandfather of Yoshimoto IMAGAWA), and in the generation of Nobusada, a son of Sadashige, since Imagawa clan was extinguished, Sadashige served Kiyohide NAKAGAWA in Settsu and called himself as Irie Tosanokami Guard and was known as one of Nakagawa sixteen horse, but died in Ozaki-no-jin.

Moreover, Sadanobu's son Sadashige served Yoshitada IMAGAWA (the grandfather of Yoshimoto IMAGAWA); and in the generation of Nobusada a son of Sadashige, because the Imagawa clan was extinguished, Sadashige served Kiyohide NAKAGAWA in Settsu and called himself the Irie Tosanokami guard; he was known as one of the "sixteen horses of Nakagawa" but died in Ozaki-no-jin.

Moreover, Sadanobu's son Sadashige served Yoshitada IMAGAWA (the grandfather of Yoshimoto IMAGAWA). After the Imagawa clan was destroyed during Nobusada's lifetime, Sadashige's son served Kiyohide NAKAGAWA in Settsu, calling himself the guardian of Irie Tosanokami. He was known as one of the "sixteen horses of Nakagawa", but died during the Battle of Ozaki.
sen.cmt: "extinguished" and "in the generation of" sound odd here so I have rewritten these parts of the sentence. Also, a native speaker of English is unlikely to know what "XXX-no-jin" means so this should be rendered in English as "the Battle of XXX".

sen.j: また入江土佐守（信定）の子・政俊は越前国の柴田氏に仕え、若狭守と称し越前丸岡城にあったが、柴田勝家と共に北庄城で滅んでしまった。
sen.e: Then, Irie Tosanokami Guard (Nobusada)'s son Masatoshi served Shibata clan in Echizen-no-kuni, called himself as Wakasamori Guard, and was in Echizen-Maruoka-jo Castle, but died in Hokujo-jo Castle together with Katsuie SHIBATA.

Then, Irie Tosanokami guard (Nobusada)'s son Masatoshi served the Shibata clan in Echizen-no-kuni, called himself the Wakasamori guard; he was stationed in Echizen-Maruoka-jo Castle but died in Hokujo-jo Castle together with Katsuie SHIBATA.

Then, Irie Tosanokami guard (Nobusada)'s son Masatoshi served the Shibata clan in Echizen-no-kuni, called himself the Wakasamori guard; he was stationed in Echizen-Maruoka-jo Castle but died in Hokujo-jo Castle together with Katsuie SHIBATA.

sen.j: 政俊の子・長行は、徳川家康の子で結城家へ養子入りした結城秀康に用いられるが、住友家の武家の歴史はここまでである。
sen.e: Masatoshi's son Nagamichi was employed by Hideyasu YUKI who was a son of Ieyasu TOKUGAWA and was adopted as son-in-law by Yuki Family, which is the end of the history of Sumitomo Family as a Samurai family.

Masatoshi's son Nagamichi was employed by Hideyasu YUKI, who was a son of Ieyasu TOKUGAWA and was adopted as a son-in-law by the Yuki Family, thus ending the history of the Sumitomo as a Samurai family.

Masatoshi's son Nagamichi was employed by Hideyasu YUKI, who was a son of Ieyasu TOKUGAWA and was adopted as a son-in-law by the Yuki Family, thus ending the history of the Sumitomo as a Samurai family.

sen.j: 戦国の習いとはいえ、武家社会の興亡の激しさと無情を感じたのか長行は、自分の子供たちに武家の世界から足を洗わせた。
sen.e: Nagamichi, who might have felt severity and heartlessness of ups and downs of the society of Samulai family although that was the way of Sengoku, ordered his children to leave the world of Samurai family.

sen.j: 長行の二男で兄の興兵衛に代わって家督を継いだ住友政友は、天正年間に生まれ、涅槃宗 (日本)の開祖、空源乃意上人にしたがって仏門に入り「文殊院空禅」と称した。
sen.e: Nagamichi's second son, Masatomo SUMITOMO, who inherited the family estate instead of his elder brother Kobe, was born in the Tenpo era, studied under Giyuishonin-Kugen, founder of Nehan-shu sect, and became a Buddhist to call himself as "Monjuin Kuzen."

Nagamichi's second son, Masatomo SUMITOMO, who had inherited the family estate instead of his elder brother Kobe, was born during the Tenpo era, studied under Giyuishonin-Kugen (the founder of the Nehan-shu sect) and became a Buddhist who called himself "Monjuin Kuzen."

Nagamichi's second son, Masatomo SUMITOMO, who had inherited the family estate instead of his elder brother Kobe, was born during the Tensho era, studied under Giyuishonin-Kugen (the founder of the Nehan-shu sect) and became a Buddhist who called himself "Monjuin Kuzen."

sen.j: 宏学達識で涅槃宗の後継者と見られていたが、寛永年間に涅槃宗が天台宗に吸収されたのを機に還俗し、洛中に、書籍と医薬品を商う「富士屋」を開き、号を嘉休と称し修道三昧の生活を始めた。
sen.e: Being omniscient and considered as the successor of Nehan-shu sect, Masatomo came back to secular life after Nehan-shu sect was absorbed into Tendai-shu sect in the Kanei era, and opened "Fujiya" dealing with books and pharmaceuticals in Rakuchu, named the go Kakyu, and started the hardworking life.

Masatomo, who was considered the omniscient successor of the Nehan-shu sect, returned to secular life after the Nehan-shu sect was absorbed into the Tendai-shu sect during the Kanei era and opened "Fujiya," a business dealing with books and pharmaceuticals in Rakuchu (called the go-Kakyu), and started a hardworking life.

Masatomo, who was considered the omniscient successor of the Nehan-shu sect, returned to secular life after the Nehan-shu sect was absorbed into the Tendai-shu sect during the Kanei era and opened "Fujiya," a business dealing with books and pharmaceuticals in Rakuchu (called himself Kakyu), and started a hardworking life.
sen.cmt: the go-削除（号を訳してもわかりにくいので、嘉休と名乗ったと訳しました。）

Riemon Soga, who was the husband of Kakyu's elder sister and a dealer in copper who believed in the Nehan-shu sect and was a Buddhist parishioner of Ku-zen (Masatomo), gave Masatomo material and mental support when Masatomo returned to the secular life and opened "Fujiya."

sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処ウェブサイト上でも原文の「女の子には、」の後に続くべき文が切れているようです。従って、「一原文一訳文の例外対処」として、文を分けましたが、前半は訳文でも途中で終っているかたちになっています。ご了承ください。

sen.j: 嘉休の姉婿にあたる銅師で、涅槃宗の信徒であり、空禅（政友）の檀家であった蘇我理右衛門は、空禅が還俗して「富士屋」を開く際、物心両面で政友を助けた。
sen.e: Riemon Soga, who was the husband of Kakyu's elder sister and a dealer in copper who believed in the Nehan-shu sect and was a Buddhist parishioner of Ku-zen (Masatomo), gave Masatomo material and mental support when Masatomo returned to the secular life and opened "Fujiya."

sen.j: 南蛮吹き
sen.e: Nanban-fuki, copper refining method
Nanban-fuki, a method of refining copper
Nanban-fuki, a method of refining copper

sen.j: 住友家と精銅とは、切っても切り離せないものがあるが、その端緒となったのは、理右衛門が、天正19年、泉州堺浦に来た明人の白水から「南蛮吹き」と称される粗銅から銀を分離する精錬法を学んだことに始まる。
sen.e: Sumitomo Family and copper refining have close connection, which began in the year 19 of Tensho when Riemon learned the refining method to separate silver from crude copper, which was called "Nanban-fuki, copper refininhg method" by Hakusui of Minjin (from Min) who came to Senshu-Sakaiura.

The Sumitomo Family is closely connected with copper refining, which began in the year 19 of Tensho when Riemon learned the refining method used to separate silver from crude copper, which was called the "Nanban-fuki copper refining method" by Hakusui of Minjin (from Min), who had come to Senshu-Sakaiura.

The Sumitomo Family is closely connected with copper refining, which began in the year 19 of Tensho when Riemon learned the refining method used to separate silver from crude copper, which was called the "Nanban-fuki copper refining method" by Hakusui of Minjin (from Min), who had come to Senshu-Sakaiura.

sen.j: 当時の日本では、粗銅の中に、金・銀などが含まれていることが知られておらず、また金や銀を分離するその精錬技術も未知のものだった。
sen.e: At that time, it was not known in Japan that gold, silver, and the like were included in crude copper, and the refining technique to separate gold and silver was also not known yet.
At that time it wasn't known in Japan that gold, silver and the like were contained in crude copper, nor was the refining technique for separating gold and silver known.
At that time it wasn't known in Japan that gold, silver and the like were contained in crude copper, nor was the refining technique for separating gold and silver known.

sen.j: 理右衛門は、明人の白水からその精錬方法を学ぶと、その技術を秘伝としてたが、この「南蛮吹き」のおかげで、住友家は粗銅から銀を取り出して、膨大な利益を上げるようになった。
sen.e: Riemon learned from Hakusui of Minjin (from Min) the refining method and kept it secret, and thanks to the "Nanban-fuki, copper refining method," Sumitomo Family raised enormous profit by taking silver from crude copper.

Riemon learned from Hakusui of Minjin the refining method and kept it secret, and thanks to the Nanban-fuki copper refining method the Sumitomo Family gained enormous profit by extracting silver from crude copper.

Riemon learned from Hakusui of Minjin the refining method and kept it secret, and thanks to the Nanban-fuki copper refining method the Sumitomo Family gained enormous profit by extracting silver from crude copper.

sen.cmt: Again, I don't think "in the generation" is very natural so I have changed it to "during the lifetime of". I've also altered the ordering of information in the sentence to make it read more naturally.

sen.j: これが世界最大級の産銅量を誇る鉱山に成長し、重要な輸出品として日本を支えることとなると共に約280年にもわたって住友の重要な事業の柱となった。
sen.e: This developed to be a mine that boasted the world-largesnt copper production, which had supported Japan as an important export item and had been the Sumitomo's major business for about 280 years.
This developed into a mine that boasted the world's greatest copper production, supporting Japan as an important export item and serving as the major Sumitomo business for approximately 280 years.

sen.j: 今日の住友家の基礎、住友財閥の出発点は、この住友友芳が開発した別子銅山によって築き上げられたものであると言ってよく、事実、住友家の歴史の中では、この四世吉左衛門友芳をもって、「住友家中興の祖」としている。
sen.e: The foundation of Sumitomo Family today, or the starting point of Sumitomo Zaibatsu, can be said to have been built by the Besshidozan Copper mine Tomoyoshi SUMITOMO developed, and actually, in the history of Sumitomo Family, the fourth generation Kichizaemon Tomoyoshi is considered to be the "restorer of Sumitomo Family."

sen.e: Tomoito's son, the sixteenth generation Kichizaemon Tomonari SUMITOMO was also a Araragi-ha poet and on close terms with Mokichi SAITO and Jun KAWADA (he was also an executive in Sumitomo main office).

Tomoito's son, the sixteenth-generation kichizaemon Tomonari SUMITOMO, was also a Araragi-ha poet and was on close terms with Mokichi SAITO and Jun KAWADA (who was also an executive at the Sumitomo main office).

sen.cmt: Actually the tense here is OK as the sentence is structured in such a way that "since" is not being used in the sense of from a particular time in the past, but in the sense of "because". This suggests that the English is a mistranslation, however, so I have corrected it. Please check this.

sen.j: ここでは、明治に入ってからの住友家とその親族・姻戚関係について述べる。
sen.e: Hereinafter, Sumitomo Family since the Meiji era and their relatevies and marriages will be described.

Hereinafter the Sumitomo Family since the Meiji era, as well as their relatives and marriages, will be described.

sen.j: 明治に入って、住友事業は12代目吉左衛門友親と、その子13代目吉左衛門友忠の下で営まれていたが、1890年に友親、友忠が相次いで亡くなり、男系相続者が途絶してしまう非運に見舞われる。
sen.e: After entering upon the Meiji era, Sumitomo enterprise was administered by the twelfth generation Kichizaemon Tomochika and his son, the thirteenth generation Kichizaemon Tomotada, but misfortune hit Sumitomo Family that male heir extinguished because in 1890 Tomochika died and then Tomotada died.

After entering the Meiji era, the Sumitomo enterprise activity was administered by the twelfth-generation kichizaemon Tomochika and his son, the thirteenth-generation kichizaemon Tomotada, but misfortune hit the Sumitomo Family with the passing of their male heirs in 1890, when Tomochika died, followed by Tomotada.

At the beginning of the Meiji era, the Sumitomo enterprise was run by Kichizaemon Tomochika (the twelfth-generation Kichizaemon) and his son Kichizaemon Tomotada (the thirteenth-generation Kichizaemon). Misfortune struck the Sumitomo family, however, with the passing of their male heirs when Tomochika and then Tomotada died in 1890.
sen.cmt: The instruction from the client seems a little unclear to me so please check whether I have corrected this according to the client's wishes. Also, the translator needs to be careful as writing "twelfth-generation Kichizaemon Tomochika" means there have been twelve generations of the same person, which is clearly not possible. The translator should be translating the meaning, not the words. I would also expect the NC to pick up on this kind of mistake (assuming a native speaker edited this, which doesn't look likely).

sen.j: この時、住友家総理人広瀬宰平と大阪本店支配人伊庭貞剛は、友親の妻・登久に14代目吉左衛門を襲名させる一方、友忠の妹・満寿の婿養子として清華家の徳大寺隆麿を迎え、住友家の命脈をつないだ。
sen.e: At that time, sorinin of Sumitomo Family, Saihei HIROSE, and manager of Osaka main office, Teigo IBA, decided that Tomochika's wife, Toku would succeed to the name of the fourteenth generation Kichizaemon on one hand and that Takamaro TOKUDAIJI from Seiga Family would be adopted as son-in-law to marry Tomotada's younger sister Masu, whereby the blood line of Sumitomo Family was successfully maintained.

At that time the sorinin of the Sumitomo Family, Saihei HIROSE, and the manager of the Osaka main office, Teigo IBA, decided that Tomochika's wife Toku would succeed to the name of the fourteenth-generation kichizaemon on one hand and that Takamaro TOKUDAIJI, from the Seiga Family, would be adopted as son-in-law to marry Tomotada's younger sister Masu, whereby the bloodline of the Sumitomo Family could be successfully maintained.

sen.j: これが15代目吉左衛門住友友純で、徳大寺実則、西園寺公望の実弟である。
sen.e: Takamaro TOKUDAIJI became the fifteenth generation Kichizaemon Tomoito SUMITOMO, who is a brother of Sanetsune TOKUDAIJI and Kinmochi SAIONJI.
Takamaro TOKUDAIJI became the fifteenth-generation kichizaemon Tomoito SUMITOMO, as a brother of Sanetsune TOKUDAIJI and Kinmochi SAIONJI.
Takamaro TOKUDAIJI became the fifteenth-generation Kichizaemon Tomoito SUMITOMO, as a brother of Sanetsune TOKUDAIJI and Kinmochi SAIONJI.

sen.j: 実はこの清華家の徳大寺家は江戸時代に東山天皇の皇胤が養子に入っており、15代目吉左衛門友純をもって住友男爵家は、男系でたどれば近世の天皇の皇胤系に入れ替わった。
sen.e: In fact, in the Edo era, the Emperor blood line of Higashiyama Emperor was adopted by Tokudaiji Family of Seiga Family, and therefore, Sumitomo baron family since the fifteenth generation Kichizaemon Tomoito was exchanged to the Emperor blood line of the early-modern history when traced backed according to the male line.

In fact, during the Edo period the imperial bloodline of Emperor Higashiyama was adopted by the Tokudaiji Family of the Seiga Family, and therefore the Sumitomo Family was entitled to the status of baron because the fifteenth-generation kichizaemon Tomoito was exchanged to the imperial bloodline of the early-modern history when traced back according to the male line.

In fact, during the Edo period the imperial bloodline of the Emperor Higashiyama was adopted by the Tokudaiji Family of the Seiga Family, and therefore the Sumitomo Family was entitled to the status of baron because the fifteenth-generation kichizaemon Tomoito was exchanged to the imperial bloodline of the early-modern history when traced back according to the male line.

sen.j: このように、旧華族、しかも家格が最上位の摂家、清華家の家系と密接な閨閥関係にある住友家の家系であるが、住友家が旧財閥の西の横綱であるとしたらば、東の正横綱、三井家との幾重にも重なり会ったつながりがある。
sen.e: As mentioned above, Sumitomo Family has a family line with close Keibatsu, Keibatsu Blood Connection with former nobles, in particular the highest ranking Sekke, Seiga Family, and if Sumitomo Family is the west Yokozuna among old Zaibatsu, Sumitomo Family has also a close connection with Mitsui Family, the east Yokozuna.

As mentioned above, the Sumitomo Family has a family line with a close Keibatsu, Keibatsu blood connection with former nobles, particularly the highest-ranking sekke--the Seiga Family--and if the Sumitomo Family is the western yokozuna among the old Zaibatsu, the Sumitomo Family also has a close connection with the Mitsui Family, the eastern yokozuna.

As mentioned above, the Sumitomo Family has a family line with a close Keibatsu, Keibatsu blood connection with former nobles, particularly the highest-ranking sekke--the Seiga Family--and if the Sumitomo Family is the western yokozuna among the old Zaibatsu, the Sumitomo Family also has a close connection with the Mitsui Family, the eastern yokozuna.

sen.j: 住友友純の妻満寿の妹楢光の嫁いだ先が、三井十一家の一つ「三井永坂町家」の八代目当主、元三井物産社長三井高泰（守之助）に嫁いでいる。
sen.e: The family Naramitsu, younger sister of Masu who was a wife of Motoito Sumitomo, married Takayasu Mitsui (Morinosuke) who was president of former Mitsui & Co., Ltd. and the eighth generation family head of "Mitsui-Nagasakacho Family"which was one of Mitsui Eleven Families.

In the Naramitsu Family, the younger sister of Masu was the wife of Motoito SUMITOMO, married Takayasu MITSUI (Morinosuke), who was the president of the former Mitsui & Co., Ltd., and the eighth-generation family head of the "Mitsui-Nagasakacho Family," which was one of the Eleven Families of Mitsui.

In the Naramitsu Family, the younger sister of Masu was the wife of Motoito SUMITOMO, married Takayasu MITSUI (Morinosuke), who was the president of the former Mitsui & Co., Ltd., and the eighth-generation family head of the "Mitsui-Nagasakacho Family," which was one of the Eleven Families of Mitsui.

sen.j: 楢光の嫁入りの時は、大阪から東京まで、７台の貨車を借り切って婚礼衣裳を送ったという。
sen.e: When Naramitsu married into Mitsui Family, seven freight cars were chartered to send wedding dresses from Osaka to Tokyo.
When Naramitsu married into the Mitsui Family, seven freight cars were chartered to send wedding dresses from Osaka to Tokyo.
It is said that when Naramitsu married into the Mitsui Family, seven freight cars were hired to send wedding dresses from Osaka to Tokyo.
sen.cmt: "charter" is usually used for planes or boats.

sen.j: しかも三井高泰の長男高篤（元三井物産取締役）は、三井総領家である北家十代の三井八郎右衛門（高棟）の妹礼子を妻にしているので、住友家と三井家の閨閥のつながりは、単に一族と一族との結合ではなく、本家と総領家が直接に結びついた本格的なものである。
sen.e: Moreover, since Takayasu MITSUI's eldest sonTakaatsu (Torishimariyaku of Mitsui & Co., Ltd.) married Reiko who was youger sister of Hachiroemon MITSUI, the tenth generation Hokke which is Mitsui Soryo-ke family and heir, Keibatsu, Keibatsu Blood Connection between Sumitomo Family and Mitsui Family is not only the simple bond between one family and another family but also the genuine connection directly connecting the Honke and the Soryo-ke family and heir.

Moreover, since Takayasu MITSUI's eldest son Takaatsu (the torishimariyaku of Mitsui & Co., Ltd.) married Reiko, who was younger sister of Hachiroemon MITSUI, the tenth-generation Hokke, being the Mitsui Soryo-ke family and heir, the Keibatsu, Keibatsu blood connection between the Sumitomo and Mitsui families is not only a simple bond between one family and another family but is also a genuine connection directly connecting the Honke and Soryo-ke families and heirs.

Moreover, since Takayasu MITSUI's eldest son Takaatsu (the torishimariyaku of Mitsui & Co., Ltd.) married Reiko, who was younger sister of Hachiroemon MITSUI, the tenth-generation Hokke, being the Mitsui Soryo-ke family and heir, the Keibatsu, Keibatsu blood connection between the Sumitomo and Mitsui families is not only a simple bond between one family and another family but is also a genuine connection directly connecting the Honke and Soryo-ke families and heirs.

sen.j: 三井家との結びつきこればかりではない。
sen.e: But the connection with Mitsui Family is not only the one as mentioned above.
However, the connection with the Mitsui Family is not only as mentioned above.

sen.j: 先代吉左衛門友純の実兄徳大寺実則公爵の三女奉子は、三井・室町家の三井高従に嫁いでおり、さらに実則の三男で分家した旧男爵徳大寺則麿の長女鶴子、つまり実則の孫娘が、やはり三井・新町家の三井高直に嫁いでいるので、住友と三井両本家は、四重、五重の閨閥関係にある。
sen.e: Tomoko, who was the third daughter of duke Sanetsune TOKUDAIJI who is elder brother of former generation of Kichizaemon, married Koju MITSUI of Mitsui-Muromachi Family, and moreover, Tsuruko, who was the eldest daughter of former baron Norimaro TOKUDAIJI who was the third son of Sanetsune and started the branch family, that is, grand-daughter of Sanetsune married Takanao MITSUI of Mitsui-Shinmachi Family, which means Honke of Smitomo Family and Honkie of Mitsui Family have quadruple or quintuple Keibatsu, Keibatsu Blood Connections.

Tomoko, who was the third daughter of Duke Sanetsune TOKUDAIJI, who is the elder brother of the former generation of Kichizaemon, married Koju MITSUI of the Mitsui-Muromachi Family; and because Tsuruko, who was the eldest daughter of the former baron Norimaro Tokudaiji, who was the third son of Sanetsune and started the branch family, that is, the granddaughter of Sanetsune married Takanao MITSUI of the Mitsui-Shinmachi Family, which means Honke of the Sumitomo Family and Honke of the Mitsui Family have quadruple or quintuple Keibatsu, Keibatsu blood connections.

Tomoko, who was the third daughter of Duke Sanetsune TOKUDAIJI, who is the elder brother of the former generation of Kichizaemon, married Koju MITSUI of the Mitsui-Muromachi Family; and because Tsuruko, who was the eldest daughter of the former baron Norimaro Tokudaiji, who was the third son of Sanetsune and started the branch family, that is, the granddaughter of Sanetsune married Takanao MITSUI of the Mitsui-Shinmachi Family, which means Honke of the Sumitomo Family and Honke of the Mitsui Family have quadruple or quintuple Keibatsu, Keibatsu blood connections.

sen.j: また当主吉左衛門の姉婿忠輝の兄の旧子爵鳥居忠一も三井・南家八代八郎次郎の長女寛子を娶っている。
sen.e: Moreover, former viscount Tadakazu TORI, who was the elder brother of Tadateru who was a husband of the elder sister of the head family Kichizaemon, married Hiroko, who was the eldest daughter of Hachiro-jiro of Misui-Minami Family.

Moreover, the former viscount Tadakazu Tori, who was the elder brother of Tadateru--a husband of the elder sister of the head of family Kichizaemon--married Hiroko, who was the eldest daughter of Hachiro-jiro of the Mitsui-Minami Family.

Moreover, the former viscount Tadakazu TORI, who was the elder brother of Tadateru--a husband of the elder sister of the head of family Kichizaemon--married Hiroko, who was the eldest daughter of Hachiro-jiro, the eighth-generation Mitsui-Minami Family.
sen.cmt: 名字大文字「八代」ｗｐ補いました。

sen.j: この公卿を中心とした旧華族と、三井総領家である、北家、永坂町家、室町家、南家、新町家と実に三井十一家のうち、総領家を含む三井の五家との閨閥の拡がりがある。
sen.e: Sumitomo Family has the expanded Keibatsu, Keibatsu Blood Connection with former nobles including especially the above-mentioned dukes, and five Mitsui Families among Mitsui Eleven Families including Mitsui Soryo-ke family and heir, Hokke, and Nagasakacho Family, Muromachi Family, Minami Family and Shinmachi Family.

The Sumitomo Family has the expanded the Keibatsu, Keibatsu blood connection with former nobles, particularly including the above-mentioned dukes, and the five Mitsui families among the Eleven Families of Mitsui include the Mitsui Soryo-ke Family and heir, Hokke, and the Nagasakacho, Muromachi, Minami and Shinmachi families.

The Sumitomo Family has extensive connections by marriage with former nobles, particularly with the above-mentioned court noble families, as well as with five of the eleven Mitsui families (including the Mitsui Soryo-ke family and the heir); namely, the Hokke, Nagasakacho, Muromachi, Minami, and Shinmachi families.
sen.cmt: Again, please ask the translator not to use unexplained Japanese terms like "keibatsu" in their translation. Also, this is not a case of a blood relation, this is simply a relationship by marriage.

sen.j: 祠堂祭
sen.e: Shido-sai
Shido-sai
Shido-sai

sen.j: 例年4月25日に「五山の送り火」が行われる京都東山の麓鹿ヶ谷の住友家別邸だった「有芳園」で開かれる、「祠堂祭」に住友直系グループの社長や会長、相談役といった面々が集合する。
sen.e: Every year on April 25, presidents, chiarpersons, Sodanyaku of direct affiliate of Sumitomo group gather to attend "Shido-sai" held in "Ariyoshi-en" that was a Sumitomo-ke Bettei in Shishigadani in Kyoto Higashiyama where "Gozan-no-okuribi"is peformed.

Every year on April 25, presidents, chairpersons and sodanyaku of direct affiliates of the Sumitomo Group gather to attend the "Shido-sai" held in "Ariyoshi-en," which was historically a Sumitomo-ke Bettei in Shishigadani in Kyoto Higashiyama, where "Gozan-no-okuribi" is performed.

Every year on April 25, presidents, chairpersons and sodanyaku of direct affiliates of the Sumitomo Group gather to attend the "Shido-sai" held in "Ariyoshi-en," which was historically a Sumitomo-ke Bettei in Shishigadani in Kyoto Higashiyama, where "Gozan-no-okuribi" is performed.

sen.j: 約3000坪をこえる園内の一隅にある「芳泉堂」と名付けられた小さな祠がある。
sen.e: There is a small shrine called "Hosendo" in a corner of Ariyoshi-en that has an area over about 9,900 sq.,m.
There is a small shrine called "Hosendo" in a corner of Ariyoshi-en, which covers an area of approximately 9,900 square meters.

sen.j: これは、昭和15年、日本紀元2600年の祝典が行われた年であったが、また住友では、別子銅山の開抗250年にあたる年で、歴代の住友家当主や旧住友本社幹部物故者の霊を祭るため、長谷部鋭吉の設計によって典雅な持仏堂として建立された。
sen.e: The year 1940 was the year when the celebration for the 2,600th anniversary of Japan's national foundation was held, but this year was also the year for the 250th anniversary of Besshidozan copper mine opening, and to enshrine the souls of the deceased successive Sumitomo family heads and the deceased executive officers of old Smitomo Honsha this shrine was designed by Eikichi HASEBE and built as an refind hall where tablets of the above-mentioned deceased people are enshrined.

The year 1940 was the one in which the celebration of the 2,600th anniversary of the founding of the Japanese nation was held, but this year was also the 250th anniversary of the opening of the Besshidozan copper mine; and to enshrine the souls of the deceased successive Sumitomo family heads and the deceased executive officers of the old Sumitomo Honsha this shrine was designed by Eikichi HASEBE and built as a refined space where the tablets of the above-mentioned deceased people are enshrined.

The year 1940 was the one in which the celebration of the 2,600th anniversary of the founding of the Japanese nation was held, but this year was also the 250th anniversary of the opening of the Besshidozan copper mine; and to enshrine the souls of the deceased successive Sumitomo family heads and the deceased executive officers of the old Sumitomo Honsha this shrine was designed by Eikichi HASEBE and built as a refined space where the tablets of the above-mentioned deceased people are enshrined.

sen.j: 「祠堂祭」に参列を許されるのは、住友家ゆかりの者と、住友直系グループの社長会「白水会」のメンバーと、白水会卒業生（元社長）だけに限定されている。
sen.e: Those who are allowed to attend "Shido-sai"are limited to the people who are related to Sumitomo Family and members of "Hakusui-kai" that is a group for presidents of direct affiliate of Sumitomo group and graduates of Hakusui-kai (former presidents).

The people who are allowed to attend "Shido-sai" are limited to those who are related to the Sumitomo Family and members of "Hakusui-kai," which is a group for the presidents of direct affiliates of the Sumitomo Group and graduates of Hakusui-kai (former presidents).

sen.j: つまり「祠堂祭」は、住友家当主と住友直系企業グループの社長や会長、相談役らの最高経営責任者が、年に1度「物故者慰霊祭」のために、一堂に会する日である。
sen.e: That is, "Shido-sai" is a day on which family head of Sumitomo Family and the highest-ranking executive officers such as presidents, chiarpersons, Sodanyaku of direct affiliate of Sumitomo group gather once a year for the "memorial service for the deceased."

That is, "Shido-sai" is a day on which the family head of the Sumitomo Family and the highest-ranking executive officers such as presidents, chairpersons and sodanyaku of direct affiliates of the Sumitomo Group gather once a year for the "memorial service for the deceased."

sen.j: なお、4月25日は「業祖」蘇我理右衛門の命日である。
sen.e: Incidentally, April 25 is a deathday of Riemon SOGA, the "Founder of business."

sen.j: また祠堂祭の幹事は、「白水会」メンバー企業の持ち回りとなっている。
sen.e: Every year Shido-sai is organized by the company that is a member of "Hakusui-kai" by rotation.
